answer:
It is not recommended that anyone receive more than one dose of influenza (flu) vaccine in a season, except for children under 9 years of age who have never had a seasonal flu vaccine. These children need two doses.
There are two types of inactivated flu vaccines  available as part of the publicly funded (free) vaccine program. The vaccines for children protect against four strains of flu, and the vaccines for adults protect against three strains of flu.
If you have further questions, please speak with your health care provider. Find a flu clinic near you here.
Immunization Nurse
answer_formatted:
## It is not recommended that anyone receive more than one dose of influenza (flu) vaccine in a season, except for children under 9 years of age who have never had a seasonal flu vaccine.

These children need two doses.
There are two types of inactivated flu vaccines  available as part of the publicly funded (free) vaccine program.
The vaccines for children protect against four strains of flu, and the vaccines for adults protect against three strains of flu.
If you have further questions, please speak with your health care provider.
Find a flu clinic near you here.

## Immunization Nurse
question: I'm a 74 year old senior. Can or should I have both the regular flu vaccine and the quadrivalent one?
question_variation_0: can i have quadrivalent flu vaccination and regular flu vaccine
question_variation_1: can you have regular flu shot and quadrivalent one
question_variation_2: can you have the regular flu vaccination and quadrivalent one?
